ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class introduced a wide variety of literature relating to ChinaAfrica relations, which was very interesting. Through the midterm I also learned a lot about analyzing concepts and frameworks used in anthropology.
This course gave me a profound understanding of how China interacts with Africa as well as a more refined knowledge of anthropology.

I learned about the conceptual foundation of China - Africa relations.
The several layers of actors who are maneuvering these encounters.

Mainly, I learned to expand the way I think about global relations, specifically those involving two regions like China and Africa. Moreover, I learned about the countless ways one can explore cultural, economic, and political interactions.
Africa China relations

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: 
Syllabus has a broad scope and a meaningful depth. readings challenged students to think about the theoretical underpinnings of China-Africa relations

weaknesses:
Syllabus overemphasized Chinese actors and decenters African perspectives occasionally. Although course is a seminar 90% of class time is the class lecturing, and although students are engaged in asynchronous class time, such as discussion posts, no in class time is given to foster learning.

Improvements: dedicate at least 50% of class time to student discussion

The greatest strength was the combination of Professor Siu and Rundong, who brought different academic and personal perspectives on China-Africa relations. The class also provided a lot of support for the final paper, which was very helpful because the final was a research paper and I was not familiar with this kind of work. One weakness of the class is that there was not much time for class discussion. Additionally, it would have been helpful if class discussion was organized in such a way that exchange of ideas between students was encouraged.
This course was phenomenal. The readings were particularly interesting and informative.

Overall, the information and discussions of the course were well done. However, it would be more fruitful to reserve more time for class discussions after a lecture or readings to engage further with concepts and engage with peers thoughts

Overall it was a fascinating topic, and I learned a lot from the presentations that Professor Siu and Rundong gave weekly. Unfortunately, we did not tend to spare much time for discussion each week, so it ended up being more like a lecture with Q&A time at the end. I think changing the lesson structure to give at least 50% of time to seminar-style discussion would make the class even better.
More discussion

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Unsuccessful: lecturing through 2 hours of class every week made students disengaged and many stopped attending

successful: the 5 minute break. Hosting one-on-one meetings with students to work on final assignments
Inclusion of 5-mins meditation prior to lectures will be great
The lectures were recorded which was good and we had a 5 min break which is nice too

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to students who are interested in analyzing one geopolitical relationship from multiple theoretical perspectives. Professor Siu does not emphasize the economic and material relationships between China and Africa, but rather the ethnographic and methodological approaches to analyzing it.
I would recommend this to any student interested in understanding the effects of China's globalization.
I would! Its profoundly interesting and the readings span so many topics that they are bound to be interesting to many people.
Yes! The topic was very interesting, and it is graded very fairly.
If you get the opportunity to take this class, do it!
Yes. If you know about the topic already

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: there are also one on one meetings
